dt: {bc}a raised platform (as in a hall or large room)

dt.t: Mounting the {wi}dais{/wi} which had been set up for his use, he swirled the sinister cloak about him and sat down in the Abbot's chair.

et: Middle English {it}deis, des{/it} "high table, elevated platform occupied by a court or council," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}deis, dais{/it} (continental Old French {it}deis{/it} "table of honor set up on a platform"), going back to Medieval Latin {it}discus{/it} "raised table, platform," going back to Latin, "discus, kind of plate, gong," borrowed from Greek {it}dískos{/it} "discus," in Late Greek also "dish, round mirror, the sun's disk, gong" {ma}{mat|discus|}{/ma}

See note at {et_link|dish:1|dish:1}. The predominant form in Middle French is {it}dois,{/it} which should have resulted in Modern French [dwa]; the reason for the outcome {it}dais{/it} [dɛ], with the presumed shift [dwɛ] to [dɛ], is in this, as in a number of parallel cases, unclear. As pointed out by the {it}Oxford English Dictionary,{/it} first edition, the English word was, excepting Scots, out of use by 1600; the current word is an antiquarian revival, with the spelling presumably copying modern French.
shortdef: a raised platform (as in a hall or large room)
